abstract.text: Establishes  an area for tracking mouse-entered and mouse-exited events within the view and returns a tag that identifies the tracking rectangle.

inlineContent.text: A rectangle that defines a region of the view for tracking mouse-entered and mouse-exited events.
The object that gets sent the event messages. It can be the view itself or some other object (such as an NSCursor or a custom drawing tool object), as long as it responds to both
and
Data stored in the
object for each tracking event.

, the first event will be generated when the cursor leaves

when the tracking rectangle is added. If
the first event will be generated when the cursor leaves
if the cursor is initially inside
, or when the cursor enters
if the cursor is initially outside
.  You usually want to set this flag to
A tag that identifies the tracking rectangle. It is stored in the associated
objects and can be used to remove the tracking rectangle.

Tracking rectangles provide a general mechanism that can be used to trigger actions based on the cursor location (for example, a status bar or hint field that provides information on the item the cursor lies over). To simply change the cursor over a particular area, use
. If you must use tracking rectangles to change the cursor, the
class specification describes the additional methods that must be invoked to change cursors by using tracking rectangles.
In macOS 10.5 and later, tracking areas provide a greater range of functionality (see

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A pointer (also called a cursor).
An object that contains information about an input action, such as a mouse click or a key press.
The data associated with a mouse-tracking event.
Informs the receiver that the cursor has entered a tracking rectangle.
Informs the receiver that the cursor has exited a tracking rectangle.
The infrastructure for drawing, printing, and handling events in an app.
This type describes the rectangle used to track the mouse.
Establishes  the cursor to be used when the mouse pointer lies within a specified region.
Adds a given tracking area to the view.
Establishes  an area for tracking mouse-entered and mouse-exited events within the view and returns a tag that identifies the tracking rectangle.
Removes the tracking rectangle identified by a tag.
A false value.
A true value.
Type to represent a Boolean value.
A rectangle.
A value type whose instances are either `true` or `false`.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A raw pointer for accessing and manipulating untyped data.
